title: NG National Single Windows
segmentation: Hello, for those who don't know me, my name is Tom Kane and I work for BMT which is the coordinating partner and this presentation has been put together with my colleague Tackis who will be happy to answer any difficult questions you might have at the end.
So while you will sleep off your lunch, I'm going to take you through the concept of next generation national single window.
Just a little bit of background and context to start with, and then the motivation behind our work and the requirements that we developed in the process over the last six months or so.
And then I'll present the concepts and what impact this might have on transporter justics in Europe.
And then I'm going to go over the Latvia pilot solution.
Will be that we will be developing over the next couple of months.
Hopefully the first version will be ready in October this year.

So the whole concept of the single window started with the UN Recommendation 33 back in 2005, and since then there have been a number of international initiatives, notably the World Customs Organization produced their data model around a similar time, and the APEC and ASEAN communities have taken on board the UN single window concept and have been working towards similar.
Initiatives in their own regions.

For example, the Asian single window they hope to create an environment where national single windows can operate and integrate within those communities, and they also hope to include banking and insurance.
APEC's got a similar system, leaving to establishing links between their national single windows.
On an EU level we have two main driving forces.
Ecustoms is driving the development of custom single windows, particularly import control and export control systems, as part of the modernized custom code program and in parallel with that safety.

Net requirements are driving maritime transport, single windows, a lot of Member States now have national SSN or safety net applications to handle the file forms and port control reporting, and then of course we have.
Initiatives and projects like Ephrati, Marittime, the River Information Services, the equivalent in rail and road, and so on.
So the motivation behind this really is that currently regulation and transport formalities, opposing barriers to efficient trade.
There is an extensive range of requirements which are specific to countries, agencies and also modes.
As we've been discussing earlier.

Currently there is little or no useful copper cooperation between these parties or integration of systems which is meant that transporters and traders are faced with complex reporting requirements, often meaning they have to submit the same.
Piece of information twice.
As a result, there is a need to develop and manage interfaces with many different systems.
Different companies, different countries, different transport modes, which increases the financial cost to parties.
And of course also the costs associated with time and the accuracy of reporting data often suffers.
So the requirements that we distilled from this background and motivation.
First and foremost, we want to support the implementation of EU policy and all the related international regulations.
We aim to facilitate and support change management for regulatory requirements and the applications.
The software applications that are associated with that we want to provide a common standardized interface for reporting regardless of mode or country.
We also want to facilitate the exchange of regulatory information across modes and authorities.
The moment it's very much information is remains in the domain in which it was submitted.
There isn't any cross fertilization of the information.

We also aim to increase the Accessibility of statistics, particularly sustainability indicators such as carbon dioxide footprint and so on, and by doing all this we aim to harmonize and integrate and unify them.
Any single window initiatives?
That are already out there and are being Dicks.
Ripped so I'm now going to take you through the concepts that the project have project has developed which were subject to a recent change.
The paper that you have been given on the CD.
I think some of the names are very slightly different so this is the latest cutting edge version which was changed based on some discussions we had earlier this week.
So I'll explain the changes as we go along.
First of all, for any transport operation, we have some sort of business that needs to report to authorities.
We have.
We've categorized five categories of authorities, mode specific searail, maritime authorities, and so on.
Border control and Immigration Customs is the biggest one.
Perhaps food and veterinary and safety and security services such as security police and emergency medical response units and things like that.
And we've developed this common Reporting Gateway, abbreviated to CRG, which acts as a reporting point for all of these authorities, regardless of mode.
On the way, the common reporting Gateway works is whether you're reporting for customs purposes or road or rail.
You use the same interface in every country.
And you report in the format of the common regulatory schema or CRS.
Sorry to overload you with all the acronyms, so the common regulatory schema defines in a mode neutral sense, all the information that is required for transport regulation in the EU.
So using this configurable format anybody can report to any authority in any country and they use the same format for everything.
This information is then submitted to a second module which we are developing called the information exchange and this really represents the core of what we're producing.
A system to distribute the data to the authorities.
It also provides notifications.
It provides responses back to the reporting party, and it's also able to intelligently analyze the data that it has received and generate further alerts and notifications.
It also allows authorities to send extra information to each other.
For example, if one authority, for example, the security police have noticed an anomaly.
They can make relevant Port Authority, for example, aware of any incoming threat.
And we call these two concepts together.
The next generation national single window.
And there will be one of these for each Member State.

So within a Member State, businesses use the next generation national single window to report to all authorities, including customs, regardless of what is being transported and how it is being transported.
And then we had some discussion about the common reporting gateway.
There were some partners that weren't happy with a single reporting interface that wasn't in their control.
For example port based in the Netherlands raised the point that there already well established system essentially is acting as a single window.
Why do they need to receive the information second hand?

So we came up with the possibility to design the common reporting gateway in such a way that it could be distributed within the Member State so they can actually be more than one common reporting gateway.
And I'll talk a little bit more about how that works later on, so this is the situation within a Member State and supporting that we have a number of other modules which exist at an EU level.
We have a central central register of the common reporting gateways, so this gives the business is the address of where to find the reporting point for that country.
So probably a web address.

There is also an EU level information exchange which works in the same way as the national level, but it allows exchange of information from country to country and also to use systems such as safety net and traces and any other systems like that which will be developed in the future.
And then this is probably possibly the most important component.
Manage regulatory information changes the nature of regulations is a highly dynamic, and often updates regulations.
New legislation coming in.
And these these components, the common reporting gateway in the information exchange aren't any use unless they can be updated efficiently and quickly when regulations change.

So what we've produced or what we will produce is a system by which applications distributed across the EU can be updated from a central point automatically, and this is down to the fact that the applications are based on the framework and changed the framework, and a central location is automatically propagated to changes in the applications.
On a national level.
And finally, with all this information stored around the place, there is a lot of potential for generating extra extra statistics and alerts and databases.
For example, an EU ships database or environmental statistics and so on.
So, and what we've called this.

It was originally called in the paper a next generation EU single window, but after some discussions we decided that actually this name is perhaps a bit misleading, so this collection of services is now called the Central EU National Single Window Support Services.
And this is how it functions.
Basically it acts as a central hub through which the EU is able to manage and update systems as legislation changes and the changes are propagated to the national single windows automatically.

So just to go into a little bit more detail, what these components do, the Information Services provides inherent capability to provide additional services, such as statistical information through data mining and data Fusion and databases.
For example, a database of registered operators within the EU or within particular countries and ship database, maybe to rival the Lloyds Register.

The Central Register of CRG's actors and address book for businesses to look up where they need to report it also allows Member States to register their software systems when they come online and make changes to the contact details.
This component, as we've said, allows the utilaj changes an essential location, and then the national single window applications are updated automatically.

And the EU Information Exchange is a facility for sharing and exchanging information between authorities across Member States to support cooperation in safety, security and environmental risk Management an includes systems such as safety net.
Just talk a little bit more about the common report.
Gateway has a number of capabilities.
First and foremost, provides a standardized reporting interface.
The information is submitted in the common reporting schema and there is only one information.
One interface for transport formalities and customs declarations.
So multiple users using the same interface.
The interface merges the information and then distributes the data to the relevant parties.
It also performs automatic validation of submissions.
For example, it checks if dates are correct.
If procedures have been followed.

If the operators are licensed checks, if truck drivers have a license to operate in that Member State, for example, it handles inputs from a number of different parties, and it can use this distributed configuration, which I mentioned, and I'll now go into a bit more.
Detail.
So the ideal the best practice.
National single window will be a single system combining the common reporting gateway and the information exchange which businesses used to report to authorities.

However, there is absolutely no reason why these two components cannot be separated physically, so the common reporting gateway can actually be embedded or integrated with an existing system such as the Port Community system port based in the Netherlands.
The information exchange still resides in a central location, but the control of the customer facing side of the application remains with the port community system operators.
So in this situation businesses report in the same format.

The common reporting schema, so they don't have to do anything differently, but the first point of contact is the port Community system and then the common reporting gateway which is embedded within that forward.
The information to the Central Information exchange.
And then onto authorities.
And in fact these two systems cameras.
Side by side in the country, businesses can report here or here and information still goes the same place and is submitted to the authorities.
And that process is transparent to the user.
A little bit more detail about.
Information exchange Now the capabilities first and foremost it's sentences.
Admissions the regulatory submissions to the correct authorities, and it integrates existing systems.
We don't want to replace systems in countries with our concept.
There are already many customs applications.
Safety net applications that are working fine.
We don't want to replace them all.
We simply want to connect them altogether and allow them to share their information.

In doing so, we are providing a central neutral database of all this information, which authorities can have access to the access rights defined by the Member State depending on their national legislation.
It also allows information to be exchanged with other countries, other authorities in other countries.
Can also intelligently analyze the data if you use the data to generate alerts, notifications, statistics and so on.
It can also be fused.
